metadata.case_name: Harbhajan Singh v. Surinder Singh Kairon

facts.text: On July 22/23, 1957, Punjab Government issued a Press Note denying complicity of a Minister's son in smuggling, challenging Urdu Dailies to name him openly.
Appellant published statement in Blitz on July 23, 1957, naming Surinder Singh Kairon as leader of smugglers and responsible for crimes in Punjab, responding to Government challenge.
Statement republished in extracts in Times of India and other papers.
Surinder Singh Kairon filed complaint on August 17, 1957, alleging defamation under S.500 IPC.
On July 25, 1957, Ajaib Singh, SSP Amritsar, issued statement denying Minister's son involvement in smuggling, published in Tribune on July 26.
Appellant issued rejoinder published in Hind Samachar on July 27, 1957.
Case filed in Court of Magistrate First Class, Tarn Taran; appellant moved Supreme Court under S.527 CrPC for transfer.
Supreme Court on October 4, 1957, directed transfer to Punjab High Court for further transfer to Sessions Court in Delhi.
Trial by Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi; complainant examined himself and three witnesses proving status and harm to reputation.
Appellant examined under S.342 CrPC, filed written statement claiming truth and public good (1st Exception) or good faith for public good (9th Exception).
Appellant sought 328 witnesses and documents; court allowed 35, examined 20.
Trial court convicted under S.500 IPC, sentenced to 1 year simple imprisonment, rejecting both exceptions.
Appeal to Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 86-D of 1959; appellant pressed only 9th Exception, alleged prejudice in evidence opportunity.
High Court confirmed conviction, reduced sentence to 3 months SI and Rs.2000 fine (3 months default).
Appellant is State Secretary of Punjab Praja Socialist Party, public worker, no personal animus.
Newspapers published reports against Minister's son without naming; MLAs made statements in Assembly.
Witness Jagat Narain (MLA) received complaints about Minister's son complicity in smuggling from newspapers and orally.
Sajjan Singh informed appellant in 1957 about smuggling, Hazara Singh, Shinghara Singh etc. as smugglers, police inaction due to connection with complainant.

Kulwant Rai faced cases under FERA, Land Customs Act, Sea Customs Act for gold smuggling; cases withdrawn per Home Secretary letter May 18, 1957; affidavit May 21, 1957; telegram by complainant for absence.
Complainant friendly with Kulwant Rai and Hazara Singh; seen together in elections 1952, 1957.
Hazara Singh from same village as complainant, treated as bad character in police records.
Principal Dewett incident 1953: complainant threatened students with stick at college, caused strike; confidential report describes ugly situation.
Vice-Chancellor report: complainant bumptious, throws weight about.
Complainant letters: to SSP for leave to constable (1957-02-20), to Executive Officer no octroi obstruction for trucks (1956-06-03).
Hardin Singh arrested as suspect smuggler June 19-25, 1959, after summoned as witness.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant made the imputation in good faith for protection of public good under Ninth Exception to S.499 IPC.
Nature and extent of onus on accused to prove exception under S.105 Evidence Act - preponderance of probability vs. beyond reasonable doubt.
Definition of good faith under S.52 IPC - due care and attention.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned statement true and for public good (First Exception), or made in good faith for public good (Ninth Exception).
High Court misdirected on burden of proof for good faith, requiring proof as strict as prosecution's beyond reasonable doubt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.105 Evidence Act; precedents like Woolmington

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court confused requirements of First and Ninth Exceptions, demanding proof of truth.
Acted with due care and attention based on information from witnesses, documents, public discussions.
Prejudiced by trial court limiting witnesses/documents.

respondent_arguments.text: Statement defamatory per se, untrue; appellant failed to prove good faith or truth.
No prejudice in evidence opportunity; examined 20/35 witnesses, documents flimsy.

court_reasoning.text: High Court misdirected on onus for exception: accused needs preponderance of probability, not beyond reasonable doubt; burden then shifts but prosecution retains original onus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Onus on accused under exception is like civil standard.

court_reasoning.text: High Court confused Exception 1 (truth + public good) with Exception 9 (good faith + public/interest); proof of truth not required for Ninth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Good faith under S.52 IPC: done with due care and attention, rational basis, not blind belief.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant showed good faith: no personal malice, response to Govt challenge, information from MLAs, party workers, police records, incidents like college threat, friendships with smugglers/bad characters.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preponderance of probability established; public good admitted.

court_reasoning.text: Written statement not afterthought: consistent with early witness list and documents sought.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No general distrust of written statements.

court_reasoning.text: Witness reluctance due to fear, e.g., arrests, supports credibility of prior information.

holdings.text: Publication protected under Ninth Exception to S.499 IPC as made in good faith for public good.
Onus under exceptions is preponderance of probability, not beyond reasonable doubt.
Good faith requires due care and attention per S.52 IPC, not infallibility or proof of truth.

precedents_cited.case_name: Woolmington v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; exceptions shift burden to preponderance.
Accused under presumption rebuts by probability, not beyond doubt.
No stringency for accused as for prosecution.
Public policy exception for prosecution onus.
Good faith: reasonable belief after due care.
Good faith needs due care, not infallibility; context matters.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tilkeshwar Singh v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Written statements deprecated but not prejudicial unless shown.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No provision for written statements at Sessions with jury.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Defamation definition and exceptions; good faith definition applied to find protection under Ninth Exception.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Burden on accused for exceptions, discharged by preponderance.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted with IPC S.52 good faith definition.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the conviction and sentence by High Court and trial court, holding appellant entitled to protection of Ninth Exception to S.499 IPC as imputation made in good faith for public good.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal; conviction and sentence set aside.

key_quotes.text: "It is sufficient if he succeeds in proving a preponderance of probability, for then the burden is shifted to the prosecution which has still to discharge its original onus."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines standard of proof for accused under exceptions.

key_quotes.text: "Nothing is said to be done or believed in good faith which is done or believed without due care and attention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes S.52 IPC defining good faith.

key_quotes.text: "Good faith requires not indeed logical infallibility, but due care and attention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains good faith test from precedent.

key_quotes.text: "If the Punjab Government accepts this challenge, it should do so by appointing an independent committee of impartial Judges."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Shows appellant's offer for inquiry, supporting good faith.
